section.title: Background Color or Image
section.para: By default, Multigraph draws a solid white background behind every graph. You can specify an alternate background color, and or an image to be used in the background of a graph, via the background tag. The background tag, if it is present at all, should appear at the top level of the &Mugl; file, inside the &mugl; tag. It accepts a single optional attribute:

listitem.para: The color to use for the graph background. The default is white ("0xffffff").

section.para: The img subtag, which may optionally appear inside the background tag, can be used to specify an image to be drawn in the background. It accepts the following attributes:

listitem.para: The URL of the image to be used. This URL may be either relative (to the location of the Multigraph SWF file), or absolute. If it is on a different server from the Multigraph SWF file, the normal constraints of Flash security apply (i.e. access must be allowed by a crossdomain file on the server containing the image).

These attributes specify where the background image should be drawn in the graph, according to the conventions described in . base is the location of the base point relative to either the padding box or the plot area (the default is the padding box; see the frame attribute below); the default value for base is "-1 -1" --- i.e. the upper left corner. The default for anchor is also "-1 -1", which means that the upper left corner of the image is anchored to the base point. position is a coordinate pair of pixel offsets, as described in ; its default value is "0 0".

The frame attribute determines whether the background image is positioned relative to the plot area or the padding box (described in ). More precisely, it determines the coordinate system of the base point, described above. The default value is "padding", which means that the background image will be positioned relative to the padding area (the entire part of the graph that is inside the border). If you want to position the background image relative to just the plot area, however, you can specify "plot" for the frame attribute, in which case the base point will refer to the plot area.
